title: Attaching a Car Battery Cut Off Switch: A Step-By-Step Guide

steps.title: Installing your own cutoff switch is relatively easy, but please heed the cautions outlined below.
steps.content: Installing your own cutoff switch is relatively easy, but please heed the cautions outlined below. If you are skittish about playing with electricity, or not sure how to continue, consult a professional. They’ll be glad to help, and you’ll get a first-rate, firsthand education from a professional.

steps.title: A cutoff switch is installed on or near the battery, and is used primarily to prevent battery charge depletion and for long-term storage.
steps.content: A cutoff switch is installed on or near the battery, and is used primarily to prevent battery charge depletion and for long-term storage. A fused switch will maintain current to your alarm, on-board computer, central locking system, and stereo, but still prevent your car from starting - the current generated when attempting to start the vehicle will blow the fuse and shut down all electrical connections. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Buy a new switch.
steps.content: Buy a new switch. The easiest type of switch you can use is a simple terminal disconnect switch. Be sure your new switch is rated to handle the load of your vehicle’s battery. This is very important! Choosing a switch that is used, worn, or underrated can result in serious electrical problems or even fire.

steps.title: Disconnect the negative terminal (usually black, marked with a “—” sign).
steps.content: Disconnect the negative terminal (usually black, marked with a “—” sign). Do this first to avoid the possibility of electrical short circuiting or shock, neither of which are good for your vehicle or your body! [2] X Research source

steps.title: Disconnect the positive battery terminal (usually red, and marked with a “+” sign).
steps.content: Disconnect the positive battery terminal (usually red, and marked with a “+” sign). [3] X Research source

steps.title: Carefully remove the battery clamp from the negative lead and save it should you want to remove your cutoff switch later.
steps.content: Carefully remove the battery clamp from the negative lead and save it should you want to remove your cutoff switch later.

steps.title: Clean your terminals and check the fluid levels in your battery.
steps.content: Clean your terminals and check the fluid levels in your battery. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Attach the battery cutoff switch to the negative terminal, and tighten securely.
steps.content: Attach the battery cutoff switch to the negative terminal, and tighten securely. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Reattach the positive lead to the positive battery terminal, and tighten securely.
steps.content: Reattach the positive lead to the positive battery terminal, and tighten securely.

steps.title: Following the instructions that come with your switch, reattach the negative lead to the switch, and tighten securely.
steps.content: Following the instructions that come with your switch, reattach the negative lead to the switch, and tighten securely.

steps.title: Make sure the cutoff switch is turned off.
steps.content: Make sure the cutoff switch is turned off. Test the system by starting your vehicle.

steps.title: If all is works as expected, turn off the vehicle and engage the cutoff switch.
steps.content: If all is works as expected, turn off the vehicle and engage the cutoff switch. Make sure you still have power to all systems.

steps.title: Do not attempt to start your vehicle with the cutoff switch engaged, or you will blow the fuse.
steps.content: Do not attempt to start your vehicle with the cutoff switch engaged, or you will blow the fuse.
